cards.title: Intro
cards.body: A quick reference for regular expressions (regex), including symbols, ranges, grouping, assertions and some sample patterns to get you started.

cards.title: Introduction
cards.body: This is a quick cheat sheet to getting started with regular expressions.

cards.title: Introduction
cards.body:
• [Regex in Python](#regex-in-python) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Regex in JavaScript](#regex-in-javascript) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Regex in PHP](#regex-in-php) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Regex in Java](#regex-in-java) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Regex in MySQL](#regex-in-mysql) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Regex in Vim](/vim#search-and-replace) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Regex in Emacs](/emacs#search) _(cheatsheets.zip)_
• [Online regex tester](https://regex101.com/) _(regex101.com)_

cards.title: Character Classes
cards.back: A character not in the range: <red>a-z</red>

cards.title: Character Classes
cards.back: A character in the range: <yel>a-z</yel> or <yel>A-Z</yel>

cards.title: Character Classes
cards.back: A character in the range: <yel>a-z</yel>, <yel>A-Z</yel> or <yel>0-9</yel>

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Matches the start of a string.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Starts a quantifier for the number of occurrences.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Matches one or more of the preceding element.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Not a standard regex meta character (commonly used in HTML).

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Matches zero or more of the preceding element.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Not a standard regex meta character (commonly used in HTML).

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Matches any character except a newline.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: ` | Acts as a logical OR within a regex pattern.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Matches the end of a string.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Escapes a meta character, giving it literal meaning.

cards.title: Common Metacharacters
cards.back: Matches zero or one of the preceding element.

cards.title: Meta Sequences
cards.back: Negation of \v - anything except newlines and vertical tabs

cards.title: Group Constructs
cards.back: b) | Match either a or b

cards.title: Lookarounds
cards.body:
Lookaround lets you match a group before (lookbehind) or after (lookahead) your main pattern without including it in the
result.

cards.title: Characters
cards.body:
Use `\` to search for these special characters:
`[ \ ^ $ . | ? * + ( ) { }`

cards.title: Alternatives
cards.body: Order longer to shorter when alternatives overlap

cards.title: Shorthand classes
cards.back: Means not digit or whitespace, both match

cards.title: Scope
cards.back: String must begin with capital letter

cards.title: Scope
cards.back: String must end with terminal puncutation

cards.title: Modifiers
cards.back: Match multiple lines (causes . to match newline)

cards.title: Groups
cards.body:
Parser tries EACH alternative if match fails after group.
Can lead to catastrophic backtracking.

cards.title: Back references
cards.back: Match <yel>to be or not to be</yel>

cards.title: Back references
cards.back: Match non-space, then same twice more   <yel>aaa</yel>, <yel>...</yel>

cards.title: Non-capturing group
cards.body: Use non-capturing or atomic groups when possible

cards.title: Atomic groups
cards.body: "id" matches, but `\b` fails after atomic group, parser doesn't backtrack into group to retry 'identity'

cards.title: Atomic groups
cards.body: If alternatives overlap, order longer to shorter.

cards.title: Lookaround
cards.back: Lookahead, if you can find ahead

cards.title: Lookaround
cards.back: Lookahead,if you can not find ahead

cards.title: Lookaround
cards.back: Lookbehind, if you can find behind

cards.title: Lookaround
cards.back: Lookbehind, if you can NOT find behind

cards.title: If-then-else
cards.body: Match "Mr." or "Ms." if word "her" is later in string

cards.title: Examples
cards.code:
>>> sentence = 'This is a sample string'
>>> bool(re.search(r'this', sentence, flags=re.I))
True
>>> bool(re.search(r'xyz', sentence))
False

cards.title: Examples
cards.code:
>>> re.findall(r'\bs?pare?\b', 'par spar apparent spare part pare')
['par', 'spar', 'spare', 'pare']
>>> re.findall(r'\b0*[1-9]\d{2,}\b', '0501 035 154 12 26 98234')
['0501', '154', '98234']

cards.title: Examples
cards.code:
>>> ip_lines = "catapults\nconcatenate\ncat"
>>> print(re.sub(r'^', r'* ', ip_lines, flags=re.M))
* catapults
* concatenate
* cat

cards.title: Examples
cards.code:
>>> pet = re.compile(r'dog')
>>> type(pet)
<class '_sre.SRE_Pattern'>
>>> bool(pet.search('They bought a dog'))
True
>>> bool(pet.search('A cat crossed their path'))
False

cards.back: Return an iterable of match objects (one for each match)

cards.title: Functions
cards.back: Compile a regular expression pattern for later use

cards.title: Functions
cards.back: Return string with all non-alphanumerics backslashed

let regex = /apples/gi;

cards.title: replace()
replace()
cards.code:
## Regex in PHP

### Functions {.col-span-2}

| -                         | -                                                                |
| ------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `preg_match()`            | Performs a regex match                                           |
| `preg_match_all()`        | Perform a global regular expression match                        |
| `preg_replace_callback()` | Perform a regular expression search and replace using a callback |
| `preg_replace()`          | Perform a regular expression search and replace                  |
| `preg_split()`            | Splits a string by regex pattern                                 |
| `preg_grep()`             | Returns array entries that match a pattern                       |

### preg_replace

cards.title: replace()
replace()
replace()
cards.body:
boolean s3 = Pattern.matches(".s", "XXXX");
System.out.println(s3);   // Outputs: false

cards.title: replace()
cards.code:
### Pattern Fields

| -                  | -                               |
| ------------------ | :------------------------------ |
| `CANON_EQ`         | Canonical equivalence           |
| `CASE_INSENSITIVE` | Case-insensitive matching       |
| `COMMENTS`         | Permits whitespace and comments |
| `DOTALL`           | Dotall mode                     |
| `MULTILINE`        | Multiline mode                  |
| `UNICODE_CASE`     | Unicode-aware case folding      |
| `UNIX_LINES`       | Unix lines mode                 |

### Methods

#### Pattern

- Pattern compile(String regex [, int flags])
- boolean matches([String regex, ] CharSequence input)
- String[] split(String regex [, int limit])
- String quote(String s)

#### Matcher

- int start([int group | String name])
- int end([int group | String name])
- boolean find([int start])
- String group([int group | String name])
- Matcher reset()

#### String

- boolean matches(String regex)
- String replaceAll(String regex, String replacement)
- String[] split(String regex[, int limit])

There are more methods ...

### Examples {.col-span-2}

Replace sentence:

cards.title: replace()
cards.body:
String regex = "[A-Z\n]{5}$";
String str = "I like APP\nLE";

cards.title: replace()
cards.body:
Pattern p = Pattern.compile(regex, Pattern.MULTILINE);
Matcher m = p.matcher(str);

cards.title: replace()
cards.body:
String str = "She sells seashells by the Seashore";
String regex = "\\w*se\\w*";

cards.title: replace()
cards.body:
Pattern p = Pattern.compile(regex, Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE);
Matcher m = p.matcher(str);

cards.title: replace()
replace()
cards.code:
## Regex in MySQL {.cols-2} ### Functions | Name | Description | | ------------------ | :----------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `REGEXP ` | Whether string matches regex | | `REGEXP_INSTR() ` | Starting index of substring matching regex
_(NOTE: Only MySQL 8.0+)_ | | `REGEXP_LIKE() ` | Whether string matches regex
_(NOTE: Only MySQL 8.0+)_ | | `REGEXP_REPLACE()` | Replace substrings matching regex
_(NOTE: Only MySQL 8.0+)_ | | `REGEXP_SUBSTR() ` | Return substring matching regex
_(NOTE: Only MySQL 8.0+)_ | ### REGEXP

cards.title: replace()
replace()
cards.body: REGEXP_REPLACE(expr, pat, repl[, pos[, occurrence[, match_type]]])

cards.title: replace()
replace()
replace()
cards.body:
mysql> SELECT regexp_like('aba', 'b+')
1
mysql> SELECT regexp_like('aba', 'b{2}')
0
mysql> # i: case-insensitive
mysql> SELECT regexp_like('Abba', 'ABBA', 'i');
1
mysql> # m: multi-line
mysql> SELECT regexp_like('a\nb\nc', '^b$', 'm');
1

cards.title: replace()
cards.body: REGEXP_INSTR(expr, pat[, pos[, occurrence[, return_option[, match_type]]]])
